abstracts.cdata!:
The Infrastructure Rehabilitation
            Project (IRP) in Guinea-Bissau objectives were substantially
            achieved. The major and significant factors that affected
            implementation were: (a) resistance to the restructuring and
            private participation in the public transport companies, and
            (b) chronic delays in the availability of counterpart funds
            and unwillingness of other donors to participate as
            co-financiers. The Bank performance was generally
            satisfactory, while the Borrowers performance was deficient
            in implementation, particularly with respect to counterpart
            financing, lack of financial accounting, and delays in
            allowing the participation of the private sector in lie
            transport companies. The key lessons learned from the IRP
            are: (a) Project activities and their related costs need to
            be carefully analyzed and take into account the further
            deterioration of infrastructure that can occur between
            project preparation and implementation. (b) cofinancing
            should not be counted upon unless the cofinanciers give
            their firm assurances. Reliance on a substantial amount of
            cofinancing that did not materialize led to implementation
            delays, changing priorities, scaling down of the project,
            demoralized staff, and a revision in the Project Agreement.
            (c) The Borrower should make a firm commitment for the
            funding of maintenance and operations of the infrastructure.
            A Special Account should be considered and established in
            accordance with the norms of the Bank's Special Account.
